Semantic Parsing Dataset for Converting Natural Language into Cypher

analytic.title: SpCQL: A Semantic Parsing Dataset for Converting Natural Language into Cypher

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

div.p: The Neo4j query language Cypher enables efficient querying for graphs and has become the most popular graph database language. Due to its complexities, semantic parsing (similar to Text-to-SQL) that translates natural language queries to Cypher becomes highly desirable. We propose the first Text-to-CQL dataset, SpCQL, which contains one Neo4j graph database, 10,000 manually annotated natural language queries and the matching Cypher queries (CQL). Correspondingly, based on this dataset, we define a new semantic parsing task Text-to-CQL. The Text-to-CQL task differs from the traditional Text-to-SQL task due to CQL being more flexible and versatile, especially for schema queries, which brings unprecedented challenges for the translation process. Although current SOTA Textto-SQL models utilize SQL schema and contents, they do not scale up to large-scale graph databases. Besides, due to the absence of the primary and foreign keys in Cypher, which are essential for the multi-table Text-to-SQL task, existing Text-to-SQL models are rendered ineffective in this new task and have to be adapted to work. We propose three baselines based on the Seq2Seq framework and conduct experiments on the SpCQL dataset. The experiments yield undesirable results for existing models, hence pressing for subsequent research that considers the characteristics of CQL. The dataset is available at https://github.com/Guoaibo/Text-to-CQL.

div.head: CCS CONCEPTS
div.p: ? Computing methodologies ? Language resources.

div.head: INTRODUCTION
div.p: With the rapid development of social, e-commerce, finance and other industries, the real world has woven a huge and complex network. Nevertheless, graph (or network) data is difficult to manage and mine, particularly for classic relational database management systems (DBMSs), which motivated the developments of dedicated database management systems (DBMSs) (i.e., graph DBMSs) for handling graph data. Thus far, Neo4j has been one of the most trendy products of this stream 1 .

Neo4j is powered by the query language Cypher (Hereinafter referred to as CQL). The complex operations and syntax of CQL require relatively high learning costs for users-often higher than that of SQL. Therefore, as with the needs of SQL databases, a semantic parsing technology (similar to Text-to-SQL) is needed to assist users in automatically translating natural language queries into CQL.
Next, we describe the main differences between CQL and SQL and explain why existing Text-to-SQL models are not applicable for the translation of natural texts to CQL.

CQL, like SQL, is a declarative text query language with a specific focus on graphs. CQL contains resembling statements, keywords and expressions such as predicates, functions, etc. (e.g. , , , , . > 10). But unlike SQL, CQL expresses graph patterns fully, thus requiring the addition of a special clause to match these patterns in the data. CQL also uses parentheses to represent node entities (()), arrows for relationships (-->), and square brackets for the relationship type and other information (() --[: ] --> ()). Hence, the various differences between CQL and SQL make it difficult to directly apply existing Text-to-SQL models on Text-to-CQL: To address these issues, we propose a new semantic parsing task Text-to-CQL that aims at tackling the translation from natural queries to CQL in Section 3. Since there is no available data, we propose the first dataset for the Text-to-CQL task and name it SpCQL. SpCQL contains a Neo4j database and 10,000 query-CQL pairs. The Neo4j database stores a large open source knowledge graph. In addition, we manually propose 10,000 natural language queries and label the corresponding CQL statements. The details of the data are shown in Section 4.

div.head: RELATED WORK AND EXISTING DATASETS
div.p: The most similar work to Text-to-CQL is Text-to-SQL because their mutual goal is to translate natural language queries into the database executable query statements. Hence, we provide a brief introduction to Text-to-SQL.
For the Text-to-SQL task, WikiSQL [10] and Spider [9], are the two most representative datasets on which we base the design of our Text-to-CQL dataset.

WikiSQL is the main dataset used in single-table Text-to-SQL research. This dataset involves multi-domain data and contains 80,657 query-SQL pairs , and has become the most popular research data for single-table Text-to-SQL tasks. Typical solutions are sketchbased approaches, such as X-SQL [5] and ER-SQL [4]. Despite a high accuracy of SOTA models on WikiSQL (over 85%), they are still not practical because the single-table assumption is too simple to reflect real use cases.

The real-world usage scenarios are often more complex, which inspires the creation of Spider. Queries in Spider are no longer limited to single-table formulations, but are expanded to contain more complex multi-table queries. Thus, it has pointed a direction for mainstream research. For such complex query scenarios, researchers are more likely to design solutions using approaches based on Seq2Seq framework, such as RAT-SQL [8] and LGESQL [1]. The Spider dataset poses a serious semantic parsing challenge, and despite the large number of researchers working on it, the current SOTA only achieves an accuracy of 72.6%2 .

By comparison, Text-to-CQL is even more challenging, due to more complex scenarios, the difficulty of leveraging database contents on a large scale and the absence of elements such as schema, primary key and foreign key.

Also worth noting is that the Text-to-SPARQL [6,7] task is proposed for graph data operations, but because of the language similarities between SQL and SPARQL, and the higher influence and usage of SQL, it is more appropriate to use SQL as a representative example for comparison in this paper.

div.head: TASK FORMULATION
div.p: The purpose of the Text-to-CQL task is to design a model capable of transforming a natural language query into a CQL query using the graph database, shown as Figure 1. It can be expressed formally as,

div.head: Neo4j Database CQL
div.p: where G is the given Neo4j database. The database is stored in the form of G = {( , , ) | , ? E and ? V}, where E represents the node set and V represents the relation set. means the natural language query proposed by the user, which is denoted as = { 1 , 2 , . . . , }. Each denotes a token of the natural language query and denotes the total number of tokens. The result is the generated CQL.

div.head: DATASET DETAIL
div.p: In this section, we introduce the collection and annotation of the dataset, and also analyze it.

div.head: Dataset Overview
div.p: SpCQL contains two main parts: a Neo4j graph database and 10,000 natural language-CQL query pairs. We provide an instance of the query pairs in Figure 2.

div.head: Data Collection
div.p: Neo4j itself comes with a large-scale open-source knowledge graph, namely, OwnThink3 . This knowledge graph contains 140 million triplets, covering people, organizations, time, activities and many generic elements. We acquired about 6,000 natural language questions on the Neo4j database as queries from technical forum sites such as CSDN 4 and Neo4j community5 through a web crawler. To ensure that our database content can cover these queries, we adapted the entities or relations that do not exist in the database. Meanwhile, we also manually propose some natural language queries as supplements. Finally, after data cleansing, we obtained 10,000 natural language queries.

div.head: CQL Annotation
div.p: For the CQL corresponding to natural language queries, we invited 10 professionals proficient in the Neo4j database and CQL language to conduct annotation. To ensure that query-CQL pair are diverse, natural, and reflect how humans actually use databases, we allow the annotators to fine-tune the queries without changing the semantics. The annotation process is not designed with any templates or scripts to generate CQL. After the annotation, a cross-review is performed to ensure that each query-CQL pair meets usage and syntactic requirements.

div.head: CQL Analysis
div.p: We present the components of CQL queries in three parts.

Functions represent the main functional keywords in CQL queries. The most basic ones are , and , which are somewhat similar to the composition of SQL. Other included functions include but are not limited to , , ,

Operators enable operations on values, characters, lists, etc., as well as operations such as comparison and matching. The details are shown in Table 1. Patterns is the most important concept in CQL and the biggest difference from SQL. The introduction of patterns not only improves the efficiency of path queries for users, but also make them more user-friendly compared to SQL. We list all the patterns and their corresponding comments in Table 2.

It should be noted that there is a specification of a possible direction in the CQL query, i.e. a directed relational query. For example, ( )-> ( ) means the relationship from to . Such queries with directed relations pose a greater challenge for the model to generate CQL.

div.head: Categorical Statistics
div.p: We analyze the query-CQL pairs in the SpCQL dataset to show that the dataset reflects real-world usage scenarios. We first count the number of functions and operators in each query. Intuitively, the more functions and operators, the more complex the CQL corresponding to that query is. The statistical results are shown in Table 3.
From the statistics, it is clear that queries in SpCQL dataset often contain multiple functions and operators. This makes CQL generation more difficult because there are more components involved.

In addition, we count a total of 6,874 queries involving patterns. It is easy to understand that since the greatest feature of the Neo4j database is the querying of paths (i.e., patterns) on graph data, most queries in the dataset are related to patterns. For further analysis, considering that the transformation of patterns is a more serious challenge, we reveal more in-depth statistics of the queries involving patterns that fall into three categories, including 1). undirected edge queries (Ud), 2). directed edge queries (D), and 3). restricted length edge queries and shortest path queries (RS). The number of patterns for the three types is 1,645, 2,916 and 2,313 respectively. There are more cases of directed-edge queries because users usually specify a person or organization as the starting point of the query. In addition, it is also a very common usage scenario for queries with limited pattern lengths during the query process.

div.head: EXPERIMENT ANALYSIS
div.p: We design three baselines, Seq2Seq [2], Seq2Seq + Attention [2], and Seq2Seq + Copying [3]. The SpCQL dataset is divided into a training set, a validation set and a test set at the ratio of 7:1:2.

div.head: Evaluation Indicators
div.p: Akin to the evaluation of the Text-to-SQL task, we adopt the follow two indicators-Logical Accuracy and Execution accuracy-to evaluate the Text-to-CQL task.

? Logical Accuracy compares the CQL queries generated by the model with the logical form of GOLD CQL. It may contain false positives caused by conditional order because the effect of conditional order in the WHERE clause is not excluded. It is calculated as = number of with correct logic form total number of .

? Execution accuracy compares the results of CQL queries generated by the model with the results of GOLD CQL execution. Since the order of the conditions such as those in the clause does not affect the results, the effect of the order of the conditions can be ignored. It is calculated as
number of with correct execution result total number of . Find all shortest paths. size((n)->()->())
Count the paths matching the pattern.

div.head: Result Analysis
div.p: We present the results of the three aforementioned baselines for comparison in Table 4. The performances of Seq2Seq baseline models are poor, exposing their weakness to solve complex queries due to its generic decoding process. This is especially true for cases where CQL contains patterns or even directed graph relations, which are the most common scenarios when using CQL for queries. In addition, the timely addition of the attention and replication mechanisms does not help much due to the Seq2Seq model's deficit such as repeated decoding.

We purposely conduct comparison experiments on the schema query problem and compare the performance of three baselines under three schema queries, and show the results in Table 5. It can be found that the results are undesirable, especially in the queries on directed edge CQL and the queries on restricted edge length and shortest path. It appears that the complexity of these queries overwhelms the baselines.

div.head: CONCLUSION
div.p: In this paper, we have introduced SpCQL, the first Text-to-CQL dataset for the popular graph database query language Cypher. SpCQL consists of two parts-a graph database in Neo4j and 10,000 natural language-CQL pairs of queries. Based on this dataset, we define a new challenging and realistic semantic parsing task that converts queries in natural language to ones in Cypher.

Advancing this task based on this dataset will further enhance the user-friendliness of current graph databases, and will also reduce the learning and usage costs. Considering the fundamental differences between SQL and CQL, this new dataset is expected to open up and inspire research opportunities for the Text-to-CQL task. Incidentally, the importance of Text-to-CQL is also reflected in its applications in other databases that use Cypher as the operating language.

figure.head: Figure 2 :
figure.figDesc: Figure 2: An instance of the dataset.

(n:Person {name: $value}) Node with the declared properties. ()-[r {name: $value}]-() Matches relationships with the declared properties. (n)->(m) Relationship from n to m. (n)-(m) Relationship in any direction between n and m. (n:Person)->(m) Node n labeled Person with relationship to m. (m)<-[:KNOWS]-(n) Relationship of type KNOWS from n to m. (n)-[:KNOWS|LOVES]->(m) Relationship of type KNOWS or of type LOVES from n to m. (n)-[r]->(m) Bind the relationship to variable r. (n)-[*1..5]->(m) Variable length path of between 1 and 5 relationships from n to m. (n)-[*]->(m) Variable length path of any number of relationships from n to m. (n)-[:KNOWS]->(m {property: $value}) A relationship of type KNOWS from a node n to a node m with the declared property. shortestPath((n1:Person)-[*..6]-(n2:Person)) Find a single shortest path. allShortestPaths((n1:Person)-[*..6]->(n2:Person))
